net.tmachine.gpg.hue
Class HUDManager

java.lang.Object
  net.tmachine.gpg.hue.HUDManager
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.util.EventListener, java.awt.event.MouseListener, java.awt.event.MouseMotionListener
public class HUDManager
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.awt.event.MouseListener, java.awt.event.MouseMotionListener

The main Model and Controller (in MVC terms) for managing the HUDs system.

Keeps track of all HUDS, and contains the preferred methods for changing their state (allowing you to hook into just one place to capture state changes etc, e.g. for propagation to listeners)

          Activates the HUD; since a HUD cannot be invisible and active, it is implicitly made visible at the same time; active HUDs receive input events, e.g mouse movement and keyboard presses.

De-activates the HUD, so that it gets NO input events, and cannot respond as a tool/control Inactive HUDs can still paint, if they are also visible.

See Also:
activateHUD(HUD)

activateHUD

public void activateHUD(HUD h)
Activates the HUD; since a HUD cannot be invisible and active, it is implicitly made visible at the same time; active HUDs receive input events, e.g mouse movement and keyboard presses.

See Also:
deActivateHUD(HUD), showHUD(HUD)

getActiveHUDs

public java.util.ArrayList getActiveHUDs()
Only returns HUDs that are both active and visible (assumes that invisible HUDs, which cannot give feedback on what the user is doing, should not be counted active - but leaves them "isActive() == true" so that as soon as they are made visible again they will automatically become active)

Returns:

setExclusiveActiveHUD

public void setExclusiveActiveHUD(HUD h)
Enables a HUD to temporarily mask out all currently active HUD's in favour of one in particular; once that HUD has completed it's action, it should call exitExclusiveHUD to re-enable all previously active HUDs.

This is a convenient way of making tools that e.g. need to engage in a multiple-stage dialog with the user within the edit window, without risking propagating input events to other HUDS.

This is typically used for complex actions, such as creating a 3D object: the gesture that triggers the create action within the main renderer will mask out everything else because it needs to exclusively capture the next few clicks (e.g. one drag to set size in one plane, followed by a click or release, then a second drag or move followed by a click to set the size in the perpendicular plane, since a 3D object cannot easily be sized using a 2D mouse cursor without this multiple-stage interaction).

Parameters:
h - the HUD to make active whilst all others are masked out
See Also:
exitExclusiveActiveHUD()

exitExclusiveActiveHUD

public void exitExclusiveActiveHUD()
Restores all the previously active HUDs to their active state

See Also:
setExclusiveActiveHUD(HUD)
